Development and Debugging Aids

Send comments on this topic.
FlashFX Tera includes a number of mechanisms which can be used to troubleshoot and debug problems, which include:

  • Building with a higher debug level.
  • Turning on various debug trace message levels.
  • Using RAM and FILE FIMs to Emulate NOR Flash.
  • Using the NAND Simulator to Emulate NAND Flash using RAM or a file.
  • Turning on the Read-Back-Verify Functionality.
Note -- Some debugging features are implemented in DCL, and are enabled and configured in dclconf.h. See the "Debugging" section in the DCL portion of the documentation for more information on using these features.

Debug Levels

Generally debug level 1 is sufficient for debugging most issues. Debug levels 2 and 3 should only be used if level 1, as well as the trace classes described next are not sufficient.

Trace Message Classes

The ffxconf.h file contains a FFXTRACEMASK setting, which is a bit-mapped mask of FFXTRACEBIT_class values that filter debug output created by the FFXTRACEPRINTF macros used throughout FlashFX. The various trace classes are defined in fxtrace.h.

Testing FlashFX Tera with Emulated NOR Flash

FlashFX Tera includes a RAM based FIM norram.c, which emulates NOR flash using RAM, and a file FIM, norfile.c, which emulates NOR flash using a file.

Building and testing FlashFX Tera using a RAM or file based FIM allows you to test the operation of the FlashFX Tera device driver independently from the FIM required to access the real flash memory. Additionally, this FIM may be useful in emulation environments.

To use this FIM, simply specify it in the ffxconf.h file, and set the MaxDevSizeKB field in the FFX_DEV0_SETTINGS definition to the size disk you wish to use.

Ensure that the device driver is configured to automatically format the disk if it detects that it does not contain a valid FlashFX Tera disk.

See the FIM source code for more information on special configuration options for this FIM.

Testing FlashFX Tera with Emulated NAND Flash

FlashFX Tera includes a NAND Simulator which has the capability of using RAM or file based storage to emulate NAND flash.

Building and testing FlashFX Tera using a RAM/File based NTM allows you to test the operation of the FlashFX Tera device driver independently from the NTM required to access the real flash memory. Additionally, this NTM may be useful in emulation environments.

To use this NTM, simply specify that the NAND FIM, and "sim" NTM be used in the ffxconf.h file, and set the MaxDevSizeKB field in the FFX_DEV0_SETTINGS definition to the size Disk you wish to use.

Ensure that the device driver is configured to automatically format the disk if it detects that it does not contain a valid FlashFX Tera disk.

See the NTM source code for more information on special configuration options for this NTM.

Using Read-Back-Verify Functionality

Read-back-verify is a feature that causes FlashFX Tera to immediately read back, and verify everything immediately after it is written. This feature is highly useful when implementing new FIMs or NTMs.

Two levels of read-back-verify are supported, at the DevMgr and MediaMgr levels. These are configured using the following settings in ffxconf.h: 

        +-------------------------------------------------------------+
        |                                                             |
        |  #define FFX_DEVMGR_READBACKVERIFY       FALSE              |
        |  #define FFX_MEDIAMGR_READBACKVERIFY     FALSE              |
        |                                                             |
        +-------------------------------------------------------------+

Set one or both of these values to TRUE to enable this functionality. Should the verification fail, the functions will internally display an error message and assert.
